title: 108_s1932
content: The Act may be cited as the "Artists' Rights and Theft Prevention Act of 2004" or the "ART Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that intellectual property, including music, film, and software, is crucial for innovation and economic development. These industries contribute significantly to the US economy, accounting for over 5% of GDP and nearly 6% of employment. The Act aims to address the illegal reproduction and distribution of intellectual property through the Internet and technology. The No Electronic Theft (NET) Act was passed in 1997 to combat illegal reproduction and distribution of copyrighted materials. It strengthens copyright and trademark laws to prosecute individuals involved in large-scale infringement. Enforcement of copyright infringements is resource-intensive and poses challenges, requiring broader deterrence for egregious violations. Enforcement of copyright infringements, particularly in cases of prerelease commercial works, is resource-intensive and poses significant challenges. The use of camcorders in movie theaters to make illegal copies of films is a serious threat to the motion picture industry, with a high percentage of first copies available for download originating from camcorders. Online theft of music, film, software, and intellectual property continues to rise, causing a significant negative impact on the US economy, such as a 31% drop in music industry sales. Federal legislation is needed to combat online theft of intellectual property due to its negative economic impact on the US economy, as seen in the 31% drop in music industry sales. This is supported by Article 1, section 8 of the US Constitution, which grants Congress the power to protect the rights of authors and inventors and regulate commerce. The importance of protecting intellectual property rights is emphasized in Article 1, section 8 of the US Constitution, which grants Congress the power to secure exclusive rights for authors and inventors and regulate commerce. The music, film, software, and other intellectual property industries play a significant role in the US economy, making theft and unauthorized distribution a common occurrence. Criminal penalties for unauthorized recording of motion pictures in a movie theater are outlined in Section 3. Section 2319B of title 18, United States Code, imposes penalties for unauthorized recording of motion pictures in a theater. Offenders face imprisonment for up to 3 years, fines, or both. Repeat offenses can lead to imprisonment for up to 6 years. Additionally, the court may order the forfeiture and destruction of unauthorized copies of protected works. When convicted of unauthorized recording of motion pictures in a theater, the court can order the forfeiture and destruction of illegal copies and related equipment. Lawful investigative activities are exempted. Theater owners and employees have immunity to detain suspects reasonably. The owner or lessee of a theater, their authorized agents, or employees, and licensors of a motion picture being exhibited have immunity to detain suspects suspected of violating the unauthorized recording of motion pictures law. Victims of the offense can submit a victim impact statement during the preparation of the presentence report. Victims of an offense under this section can submit a victim impact statement to the probation officer, detailing the injury, loss, and economic impact suffered. The statement must include information about producers, sellers, and holders of legitimate works affected by the offense. Definitions of terms like 'audiovisual work' and 'copyright owner' are provided in this section. In this section, definitions for terms like 'audiovisual work' and 'copyright owner' are provided. It also defines an 'audiovisual recording device' as any technology capable of recording copyrighted motion pictures. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the United States Code. The term 'motion picture exhibition facility' is defined as a venue primarily used for showing copyrighted movies to the public. Additionally, criminal infringement of a work being prepared for commercial distribution is addressed. The amendment to Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code, specifies that criminal infringement of a copyright will result in punishment if done for commercial gain, distributing copyrighted works worth over $1,000, or sharing works intended for commercial distribution on a public computer network. The amendment to Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code, states that criminal infringement of a copyright for commercial gain, distributing copyrighted works worth over $1,000, or sharing works intended for commercial distribution on a public computer network may result in punishment. Willful infringement of a copyright requires more than just evidence of reproduction or distribution of a copyrighted work. The term 'work being prepared for commercial distribution' includes computer programs, musical works, motion pictures, sound recordings, and motion pictures that have not been commercially distributed but have a reasonable expectation of commercial distribution. The amendment to Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code, expands criminal penalties for copyright infringement, including unauthorized distribution of works intended for commercial distribution or motion pictures not yet commercially available. The code is amended to increase penalties for offenses under section 506(a)(1)(C) of title 17, with imprisonment up to 6 years for offenses committed for commercial advantage or financial gain. The amendment to Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code, increases penalties for copyright infringement, with imprisonment up to 10 years for repeat offenses committed for commercial advantage or financial gain. The term 'financial gain' is defined in section 101 of title 17. The amendment increases penalties for copyright infringement, with imprisonment up to 10 years for repeat offenses committed for commercial advantage or financial gain. The term 'financial gain' is defined in section 101 of title 17. The amendment also includes definitions for 'financial gain' and 'work being prepared for commercial distribution' in section 506(a) of title 17. Civil remedies for infringement of a work being prepared for commercial distribution are outlined in section 5. Preregistration procedures for works being prepared for commercial distribution are outlined in section 408 of title 17, United States Code. The Register of Copyrights will issue regulations for preregistration within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. Preregistration is allowed for works with a history of infringement before authorized distribution, and applicants must submit an application, deposit, and fee within 3 months of first publication. The applicant must submit an application, deposit, and fee to the Copyright Office within 3 months of first publication to register a work. Failure to do so may result in dismissal of an infringement action and no award of damages or fees for a preregistered work. Infringement actions cannot be initiated until preregistration or registration is completed. Section 411(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to require preregistration or registration before initiating infringement actions. Section 412 is also amended to exclude actions for infringement of preregistered works. Federal sentencing guidelines are addressed in Section 6. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and potentially amend sentencing guidelines for intellectual property crimes within 180 days of this Act. They are authorized to make amendments following specific procedures. The Commission must ensure guidelines are appropriate. The United States Sentencing Commission is responsible for ensuring that sentencing guidelines for intellectual property crimes are stringent and reflective of the nature of the offenses. They will consider providing sentencing enhancements for unauthorized distribution of copyrighted works and assess the adequacy of guidelines for addressing losses from widespread distribution of copyrighted materials. The United States Sentencing Commission will assess if the current guidelines adequately address losses from widespread distribution of copyrighted materials over the Internet. They will also consider if sentencing guidelines reflect the harm to victims from copyright infringement when the extent of reproduction or distribution is unknown. Authorization of appropriations of $5,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2005-2009 to prosecute violations of intellectual property rights under specified sections of title 18, United States Code.
